Award.AwardTitle: Systematic Control Algorithms and Computational Tools for Complex Distributed Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop rigorous control algorithms and complexity reduction tools for high-performance systems interconnected over general graph structures, where the controller sensing and actuation topology is inherited from that of the plant. The research will provide a new operator theoretic framework that can capture complex distributed systems composed of heterogeneous, non-stationary linear parameter-varying (NSLPV) subsystem models interconnected over potentially infinite graphs, with delays incorporated between and within the subsystems. Using this framework, the state-space equations of the distributed system can be represented in a compact operator form which is reminiscent of standard state-space equations, and many derivations and proofs of robust control results on single standard state-space systems can be adapted to NSLPV systems interconnected over arbitrary graphs. The results will include model reduction techniques for stable and stabilizable/detectable distributed systems and convex methods for control design, encompassing novel deterministic approaches to handling real-time changes in the interconnection structure and uncertain initial conditions. Simplified computational algorithms will also be devised for eventually periodic distributed systems.

If successful, the research will apply to a broad class of complex distributed engineering systems. Specific applications of interest are mobile sensor networks and cooperative control of multi-vehicle systems, such as ground robots or uninhabited aerial vehicles (UAVs), operating in hazardous environments or disaster zones. Undergraduate students will be involved in the research program through numerous projects. In collaboration with the Center for the Enhancement of Engineering Diversity at Virginia Tech, age-appropriate modules based on this research, along with hands-on experience with UAV flight control systems, will be provided in summer camps for middle and high school students, including women and minorities. In addition, a cross-listed graduate course on control software design will be developed, which addresses explicitly the implementation issues of control systems and related problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on developing systematic control design algorithms and complexity reduction tools for high-performance systems interconnected over general graph structures. A broad class of distributed control systems was considered, including systems composed of heterogeneous, nonstationary linear parameter-varying (NSLPV) subsystem models interconnected over arbitrary graphs, with communication latency of one sampling period. NSLPV models include linear time-invariant (LTI), linear time-varying (LTV), and linear parameter-varying (LPV) models as special cases. Such state-space models have explicit dependence on time in addition to scheduling parameters which are available for measurement during plant operation.

Two equivalent frameworks were developed to represent the distributed system equations in a compact form reminiscent of standard state-space equations. Using these frameworks, standard, well-known results in robust control theory were transparently extended to the distributed system setting, acquiring in the process new characteristics. For instance, in both frameworks, the interconnections between the subsystems are regarded as spatial states. Then, extending standard balanced truncation and coprime factors model reduction techniques to our general distributed system setting resulted in convex methods that can be used not only to reduce the computational complexity of the subsystems, but also to quantify the significance of the interconnections. Similarly, the extension of standard LPV control techniques did not only help in accounting for the effects of scheduling parameters on the behavior of the subsystems, but also provided an original approach to handling varying interconnection structures.

Model reduction techniques based on the balanced truncation and coprime factors reduction schemes, with a priori bounds on the reduction errors, were developed for distributed LTV and, more generally, NSLPV systems over arbitrary directed graphs with communication latency of one time-step. These techniques, not only give a systematic means to reduce the size of subsystems, but also allow for the systematic simplification of the network structure, which is a novel feature that is very useful for control design and implementation of networked systems.

Parameter-dependent and independent Lyapunov approaches were devised for distributed LPV systems, with the analysis and synthesis solutions provided in terms of semidefinite programming problems. Computational methods for making the semidefinite programs manageable were suggested. Fast and easy-to-implement algorithms for controller construction were derived. The parameter-independent Lyapunov approach was further extended to the case of NSLPV subsystems. The parameter-dependent Lyapunov approach was utilized in a novel way to solve networked control problems with intermittent communications, and was applied to a leader-follower formation control problem involving hovercrafts with a leader transmitting information of varying reliability.

The control synthesis problem for distributed LTV systems with uncertain initial conditions was also addressed. Uncertainties in both the temporal and spatial states of the system were considered, and convex synthesis conditions for the existence of a distributed controller were derived. This control approach provides a systematic method for improving the performance of a distributed system during switching between trajectories or topologies. An example on formation control of fixed-wing unmanned aircraft systems was provided.

The developed algorithms for general distributed nonstationary systems usually involve solving infinite sequences of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). However, for the class of eventually periodic subsystems interconnected over graphs with a finite number of vertices, it is shown that the sequences of LMIs become finite. The class of eventually periodic models is fairly general and includes finite horizon and periodic models as special cases.

The project has led to the training of two graduate students. Undergraduate students worked with the graduate students in the lab on tasks pertinent to the project. Lectures and participatory experiments, focusing on unmanned aircraft systems and utilizing some of the developed results, were prepared for summer activities organized by Virginia Tech's Center for the Enhancement of Engineering Diversity. These activities were targeted toward middle school and high school students, and specifically aimed at increasing the participation/success of students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering. Results from the project were also used in control courses and a special topics course taught by the PI.
